column9: My 14 year old daughter has taken Concerta for 5 years.  Results: somewhat academically improved.  HOWEVER: side effects were consistent with warnings posted on medication and most detrimental was difficulty sleeping.  My daughter's dosage had increased over the years, the last 8 months she was on 72mg.  Over this period we eventually noted more anxiety, parental confrontations, involuntary trembling in her hands.  We had been seeing a psychiatrist during this period.  He had prescribed Trazodone as a sleeping aid, but said the trembling was not caused by Concerta.  I finally told the psychiatrist it was time to stop or change because of concern with effects.  Psych. agreed and said there was no problem with coming off the Concerta.  Wrong again.  Day 4 fatigue.  Days 5-10 intermittent nausea, dizziness, persistent moderate to severe headaches, abdominal pains, general ill feeling.  Her appetite has dramatically increased over this withdrawal period.  Consultation with pharmacist: stated it is very TYPICAL for withdrawal symptoms when stopping suddenly after this 5 year period.  Pediatrician visit: blood tests normal, no mono or strep throat, symptoms should subside soon, take Motrin or Tylenol.  Psychiatrist still states withdrawal symptoms are "ATYPICAL," and is probably a stomach virus.  Time for a new psychiatrist.  I have done much reviewing on the web on amphetamines dependency, and just because you have a doctor prescribe it, don't think it can't harm you, or that you won't have withdrawal if you quit.  Most sources recommend tapering the dosage gradually to reduce withdrawal effects, I completely agree with that option.  My daughter has missed 5 days of school due to the withdrawal symptoms.  We are determined to avoid these drug types in the future.  There are no simple harmless drugs for ADHD that don't carry some life threatening risks.  I would rather my daughter be a slow learner than permanantly injured or killed by these "medications."

It's great to have a kid who does A work actually have the teacher see the work because tests are completed and homework is not continually lost, left on the printer, left in the car, on the steps, etc. Having resisted medication for 5 years while all else was tried, we're very happy with the result. The worry that the medication might make this laid back kid hyper turned out to not me an issue at all, and his sleep has not been impacted.
